title: My main account was banned 3-4 years ago, curious if its possible to reverse it
body:
Whats up guys. 3-4 years ago I was your classic raging tool-bag. My main account got permanently banned and I just played on my smurf. It may have even been longer then that... It's been a long time. I stopped playing for years and recently picked it back up. But here's the thing... I'm not a raging asshole anymore! I actually really enjoy my life now and I never get mad at my teammates. I believe having a great attitude is one of the best strategies for actually winning games and enjoying the game while you're at it.

My old account has almost every champion and I was just curious if there was any way to reverse this or if its just permanent. It would be nice to have access to all of my old stuff. If not, then that's completely understandable. Thanks.

Riot's punishment system used to hand out stacking chat restrictions, such that consistently toxic players basically had a permanent chat restriction. Unfortunately, it turns out that such players used their few chat opportunities to be toxic, and, when they couldn't be as toxic as they wanted to, they resorted to committing non-chat offenses such as griefing (following someone around and taking their farm, using wall abilities to interfere with their play, etc.) or inting. The purpose of the punishment system is to eliminate rule-breaking, not make it worse. Thus, if a couple chat restrictions don't make any difference in a player's misbehavior, the system ramps up the punishments until the player is permabanned and thus unable to use that account to break any more rules ever again.

However, the only people who wouldn't even see that first sign are those who /mute all at the start of every game. Everyone else would get that initial taste of your toxicity. The rules are intended to make chat _positive and useful_. If your presence means that anyone making the slightest effort to communicate in a team game has to deal with the sort of chat messages you've displayed here, that's on you, not on them. _Behave yourself._
